awd_titl_txt: 2023 Foundational Research in Robotics (FRR) - National Robotics Initiative (NRI) Principal Investigators’ (PI) Meeting; Arlington, Virginia; 1-3 May 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this project is to plan, organize, and execute the 2023 National Science Foundation (NSF) Foundational Research in Robotics-National Robotics Initiative (NRI) and the Foundational Research in Robotics (FRR) Principal Investigator (PI) Meeting. This meeting will convene all PIs of active awards of the NSF FRR and NRI Programs for the eighth time since the NRI Program began in 2011. The PI Meeting is scheduled for the Spring of 2023 in Arlington, Virginia. The program agenda is community-driven and features project talks, poster sessions, and “live” demonstrations from researchers, reports of past year program activities, special topic workshops, panel discussions, keynote talks, and Federal agency program updates from leaders in the research community. This two-day meeting will be the first full in-person PI meeting since the 2020 Covid-19 pandemic.

The annual PI Meeting will be a major national event for the NSF FRR and NRI research communities and serves as an annual forum where Principal Investigators will have opportunities to meet and share their research and best practices; discuss new research opportunities, successes, and challenges; and explore new ideas and partnerships; and to interact with Federal agency representatives, industry, and other stakeholders with vested interests in NSF robotics research and development. NSF Robotics PI Meetings have played a major role in community-building across a broad range of robotics topics, sectors, and technologies and with promoting best practices in education, technology transfer, and outreach to others who have interest in learning about the program and participating as future proposers, transition partners, or sponsors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the ninth NSF Foundational Research in Robotics - National Robotics Initiative (FRR-NRI) PI Meeting project was to coordinate the end-to-end logistical organization of the meeting. The 2023 FRR-NRI PI Meeting was held in person over three days from Monday, May 1 (arrival night) through Tuesday, May 2nd and Wednesday, May 3rd, 2023 (meeting days). The PI Meeting was fully in-person at the Hyatt Regency Crystal City at Reagan National Airport Hotel located at 2799 Richmond Highway in the Crystal City Community of Arlington, Virginia, 22202.This meeting was the first to be held in-person since 2020.

This meeting brought together the community of researchers, industry representatives, non-governmental and non-profit organizations, and Government program managers who are actively engaged in the Foundational Research in Robotics Program who are actively engaged in the Foundational Research in Robotics (FRR) and the National Robotics Initiative (NRI) programs to review the progress, challenges, and future directions of FRR and NRI research and to provide an environment for PIs to showcase their research and to network. The FRR program has assumed most of the tenants of the former National Robotics Program that was sunset in May 2022. The FRR program provides a single home for foundational research in robotics across NSF. The FRR program covers a broad spectrum of foundational research in robotics, including the topics of collaborative robotics and integration in robotics that were previously supported by NRI. Government program Directors were largely represented from the NSF CISE and Engineering Directorates, but also are represented from NIH, the Navy, and USDA.

The program of the meeting included two distinguished keynote presenters whose combined talks covered diverse foundational and domain FRR and NRI research topics. Dr. Holly Yanko (University of Massachusetts-Lowell and the Computing Community Consortium (CCC) provided the day one keynote and spoke on the topic of CCC’s Mid-Cycle Robotics Roadmap Report Update. Dr. Brenna Argall (Northwestern) provided the day two keynote and spoke on the topic of Mobility and Manipulation Independence with Interface-Aware Robotic Intelligence.

FRR-NRI PIs were directly involved in key elements of the program including:

  • leading discussions in the form of six mini workshops that covered the topics of Aspiring Robotics PIs; Disability, Accessibility, and Assistive Applications in Robotics Research; Hacking the Metaphor: An Approach to Ethical Technology Exploration; Mobilizing a Consortium for Autonomous Robotic Platforms to Strengthen Wildland-Fire Ecosystems Resiliency; Fundamental Challenges in Robotics-CCC Kick-Off to 2024 Robotics Roadmap; and Learning for Task and Motion Planning.
  • giving real-time project long talks about the thrust and progress of their research.
  • showcasing their research via one hundred fifty-nine (159) PI project posters, seven (7) project demonstration presentations, and thirty-four Aspiring PI posters.
  • interacting and networking directly with each other, Government program managers, and other stakeholders during the Agency Perspectives on Federal Robotics S&T and Ask NSF Almost Anything Panels

 Remarks were given by Margaret Martonosi (NSF CISE Assistant Director) and Susan Margulies (NSF Engineering Assistant Director). Other Federal agencies supporting the 2023 FRR-NRI PI Meeting event included the National Institutes of Health, the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and the U.S. Navy.

All public artifacts, website URLs, speaker presentations, the meeting program, meeting participant lists, and meeting organizers have been disseminated to communities of interest via the public 2023 FRR-NRI PI Meeting website which can be found at 2023 NSF Foundational Research in Robotics - National Robotics Initiative Principal Investigators' Meeting | Cyber-Physical Systems Virtual Organization (cps-vo.org).

Pre-meeting planning for this ninth FRR-NRI PI Meeting took place over a nine-month calendar period in conjunction Vanderbilt, the Technical Program leads Nora Ayanian (Brown University) and Dylan Shell (Texas A&M University), and the NSF CISE CPS PDs. Project tasks concluded with post-meeting archiving of content on the PI Meeting website and other administrative wrap-ups over a three-month period.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/19/2024
Modified by: Frankie D King
